title: How was homosexuality treated in ancient Greece versus today? - Quora

response.answer_text: Aerin Crew and Raenna Foeller have both already answered this question very well! I’ll try to build off what they said with what I know. I’ll refrain from using words like “lesbian”, “gay”, and “homosexual”, because they conjure up modern ideas and connotations that I believe distract us from being able to dive into a Greek mindset, which focuses on power rather than gender or preference. To summarize what Raenna said, ancient Greeks didn’t think of sex in terms of genitalia but in terms of power. To be penetrated was weak/feminine/younger and to penetrate was strong/masculine/older; the words εραστης “lover” and ερωμενος “lovee” describe these ideas, as Aerin stated. As Aerin also alluded to, there was a practice among some ancient Greeks of pederasty. However, this is one of the few times that I believe Wikipedia is wrong (disclaimer - I use Wikipedia a lot and I love it; I simply disagree with it on this point, specifically its article https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pederasty_in_ancient_Greece, which nonetheless provides some good information): historians and classicists disagree whether pederasty was romantic, and I don’t think it was. I’ll explain why. - Pederasty - allow me to expand on this idea. The word παιδεραστία comes from παις “child” and εραστης “lover”. Some people who either have anti-Greek or anti-queer agendas have erroneously translated this word as pedophilia. Although the components of these two words are similar, they have distinctly different connotations to the people that use them. When people say pedophilia today, they most often mean “sexual feelings towards children”, and usually this goes beyond mere feelings to actions of sexual molestation or intercourse. Pedophilia is frowned upon whether the perpetrator is LGBTQ+ or not. Pederasty, on the other hand, was a socio-political relationship between a family and their young boy, and a man in the public sphere. Men would seek out a boy, (conversely, families could seek out men, although we have far less evidence of this) to become a mentor (lover) for the boy (lovee). These boys ranged between pre-pubescence to upper teens. This stage of seeking included courtship, wooing, and getting to know the family. The boy or his father would eventually decide which mentor he would go with. Now the lover’s job was to teach the lovee how to become a man: political savviness, athletic training, music, singing, dance, and sexuality all fell under this umbrella. The lover taught the lovee how to be sexually dominant as preparation for marriage and for the lovee’s own eventual pederastic relationships. We have very little evidence of anal penetration in pederasty, but our evidence does show with overwhelmingly consensus that the lovee is rarely aroused, and that the sexual portion of this relationship was for the pleasure of the lover and not for the lovee. For this reason I don’t consider pederasty romantic, because I don’t consider molestation romantic. To be clear, the bulk of our evidence on pederasty comes from Athens; we know of other Greek cities that looked down on pederasty and even among the Athenians there was no single opinion of it at any particular time. However, pederasty seems to be the product of a pre-scholastic educational system: acceptance of pederasty seems to be a feature of the Archaic period (~799–480 BCE), and once public and even private schools became common in the Classical period (~510–323 BCE) and afterwards, the public opinion of pederasty seems to have plummeted, even in Athens. - However, that says nothing about the ancient Greeks’ opinion on same-genitalia intercourse, which remained relatively simple throughout the course of antiquity: You’re either penetrated or you penetrate, you’re either feminine or masculine. People who looked down on same-genitalia intercourse did so not because it was abominable or impure or unnatural (common accusations used in modern times), but because it upset power roles. To an ancient Greek, the problem with same-genitalia intercourse is that either a woman gets to be more-powerful/masculine (in the act of using something to penetrate someone else) or a man needs to be less-powerful/feminine (in the act of being penetrated by someone else, whether it’s by a penis or a finger or some object). It would be just as upsetting for a high-class woman to be penetrated by a low-class man as for gender-roles to be switched. It ultimately boils down to power, not gender. That’s the simplest truth of it, although it was of course far more complex than just that. - “Gay” relationships - There were conservative stances, that same-genitalia sex ought to merely compliment the more normative male-female sex. There were also more progressive stances, and there’s evidence of men foregoing marriage to enter into committed relationships that of course included all sorts of same-genitalia sex (unfortunately, I can’t find my source for this right now, but I’m positive of it!). However, this type of relationship was probably uncommon given their society; the overwhelming majority of same-genitalia relations probably happened between masters and slaves. Plato’s idealization of same-genitalia love being far greater than male-female love in Sumposion is not at all representative of common thought in Athens at the time. It does provide an example of a healthy, positive “gay” relationship, indicating that such a relationship wasn’t totally out of the question, even if it was very, very uncommon. Concerning Akhilleus and Patroklos, I doubt even the most conservative ancient Greeks would have had a problem with it being a romantic relationship. Akhilleus is one of the most powerful of the heroes, and Patroklos is both younger and less powerful. Akhilleus has a right to pursue whatever relations he wants, as long as Patroklos consents. What would be offensive to them is if someone wrote a poem about how Patroklos was always penetrating and Akhilleus was always receiving. - I hope this is a helpful summation, and please don’t hesitate to post if you have further comments or counter-point on facts you think I may have gotten wrong! Sources: Daily Life of the Ancient Greeks. Garland. Greenwood, 2008. Many lectures at the University of Washington by top classics professors with credentialed expertise in ancient sexuality and the ancient Greek mindset.

It actually was a pretty funny story! Achilles and Patroclus is the best example I can give for this. They were constantly being depicted as close, but there was a disagreement between whether they were close enough to be lovers or not. Weirdly enough, the “close friends” group was in the minority, and get this: There was constant argument based on who was erastes and who was eromenos, which technically the same argument as who was the protector and who was the protected in a gay relationship. “Pederasty in ancient Greece was a socially acknowledged romantic relationship between an adult male (the erastes) and a younger male (the eromenos) usually in his teens” (from Wikipedia) They had a name for a specific gay relationship. That seems pretty accepting to me. Modern times have been pretty accepting too. Thats great for us!
